items.synopsis: King Abdullah II of Jordan says neither Jordan nor Egypt are willing to accept any Palestinian refugees. Follow live.Â

title.children: Jordan and Egypt unwilling to accept Palestinian refugees as organisations call for urgent access to deliver aid to Gaza

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United States has responded to Hamas's release of a hostage video by calling on the group to immediately release all hostages. "There should be no reason for them to have any hostages in the first place," US National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby said on American TV Tuesday morning (local time). The terrorist group posted a video of the woman, identified as 21-year-old Israeli woman Mia Schem, to one of their social media channels earlier today. Mr Kirby said he believed it was a "propaganda video" from Hamas, telling NBC: "There's no question in my mind that that woman gave that video testimony under duress, probably forced to do it. "It's despicable, deplorable that they would take these hostages and then advertise how well they're treating them when they're the ones who hurt them in the first place." The young Israeli woman's mother has pleaded for her release, calling the seizure of hostages a "crime against humanity". "I'm begging the world to bring my baby back home. She only went to a party, to a festival party to have some fun. Now she's in Gaza," Keren Schem said at a news conference. Associated Press
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US responds to hostage video by calling for immediate release of all those held

children.content: The United States has responded to Hamas's release of a hostage video by calling on the group to immediately release all hostages.
"There should be no reason for them to have any hostages in the first place," US National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby said on American TV Tuesday morning (local time).
The video of Mia Schem was posted to Hamas's Telegram channel earlier today.
The terrorist group posted a video of the woman, identified as 21-year-old Israeli woman Mia Schem, to one of their social media channels earlier today.
Mr Kirby said he believed it was a "propaganda video" from Hamas, telling NBC:
"There's no question in my mind that that woman gave that video testimony under duress, probably forced to do it.
"It's despicable, deplorable that they would take these hostages and then advertise how well they're treating them when they're the ones who hurt them in the first place."
The young Israeli woman's mother has pleaded for her release, calling the seizure of hostages a "crime against humanity".
"I'm begging the world to bring my baby back home. She only went to a party, to a festival party to have some fun. Now she's in Gaza," Keren Schem said at a news conference.
Associated Press

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Egyptian trucks carrying humanitarian supplies have moved closer to Rafah crossing â the only road into Gaza not controlled by Israel. But with no agreement in place to deliver relief and the Palestinian side still closed due to air strikes, it's unclear when they might pass through. Some Palestinians with dual citizenship, who have gathered in recent days at Rafah crossing, began approaching the border today, but many say they are staying away due to the air strikes. After nine hours of negotiations, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken says he has agreed with Israel "to develop a plan" to get aid into Gaza. Here are photos of Egyptian volunteers gathered near the Rafah crossing, as they wait to be granted safe passage:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Humanitarian aid for Gaza civilians arrives at border crossing

props.alt: A general view of the Rafah crossing from the Egyptian side

children.content: The Rafah crossing is the only crossing point between Egypt and Gaza.
(Reuters: Stringer)
Egyptian trucks carrying humanitarian supplies have moved closer to Rafah crossing â the only road into Gaza not controlled by Israel.
But with no agreement in place to deliver relief and the Palestinian side still closed due to air strikes, it's unclear when they might pass through.
Some Palestinians with dual citizenship, who have gathered in recent days at Rafah crossing, began approaching the border today, but many say they are staying away due to the air strikes.
After nine hours of negotiations, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken says he has agreed with Israel "to develop a plan" to get aid into Gaza.
Here are photos of Egyptian volunteers gathered near the Rafah crossing, as they wait to be granted safe passage:

props.alt: Egyptian volunteers gather next to a truck convoy carrying humanitarian aid from Egyptian NGOs for Palestinians

children.content: Egyptian volunteers have gathered at the Rafah crossing.
(Reuters: Stringer)

props.alt: gyptian volunteers gather with a Palestinian flag next to a truck convoy carrying humanitarian aid

children.content: A truck convoy carrying humanitarian aid from Egyptian NGOs waits for the Rafah crossing to open.
(Reuters: Stringer)

props.alt: gyptian volunteers gather with a Palestinian flag next to a truck convoy carrying humanitarian aid

children.content: The US says it has negotiated a plan with Israel to deliver aid into Gaza.
(Reuters: Stringer)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: King Abdullah II of Jordan says neither Jordan nor Egypt would be willing to accept any Palestinian refugees, urging the humanitarian situation to be dealt with within Gaza and the West Bank. The Jordanian king told reporters earlier this evening: "I think I can quite strongly speak on behalf of not only of Jordan as a nation, but our friends in Egypt: That is a red line â¦ no refugees in Jordan, no refugees in Egypt. "This is a situation of humanitarian intervention that has to be dealt with inside of Gaza and the West Bank, and not to try and push the Palestinian challenge and their future onto other people's shoulders." King Abdullah made the comments at a press conference following a meeting with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin. About 1 million Palestinians in Gaza may have been displaced from their homes since the beginning of the war, due to air strikes and the order to evacuate the northern part of the enclave, the United Nations said in an update posted earlier. More than 2 million registered Palestinian refugees already live in Jordan, according to United Nations data. ABC with Reuters and AP
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Jordan and Egypt unwilling to accept Palestinian refugees, King Abdullah says

children.content: King Abdullah II of Jordan says neither Jordan nor Egypt would be willing to accept any Palestinian refugees, urging the humanitarian situation to be dealt with within Gaza and the West Bank.
The Jordanian king told reporters earlier this evening:
"I think I can quite strongly speak on behalf of not only of Jordan as a nation, but our friends in Egypt: That is a red line â¦ no refugees in Jordan, no refugees in Egypt.

"This is a situation of humanitarian intervention that has to be dealt with inside of Gaza and the West Bank, and not to try and push the Palestinian challenge and their future onto other people's shoulders."
King Abdullah made the comments at a press conference following a meeting with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz in Berlin.
About 1 million Palestinians in Gaza may have been displaced from their homes since the beginning of the war, due to air strikes and the order to evacuate the northern part of the enclave,
the United Nations said in an update posted earlier
More than 2 million registered Palestinian refugees already live in Jordan, according to United Nations data.
ABC with Reuters and AP
